text.p: These are some of the leading stories in the Jordanian press on Thursday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- King urges dialogue, efforts to protect democracy, meets parliamentarians from south, reviews situation after bread price riots.
- Life largely normal in Karak, residents seek end to curfew.
- Government minister Shneikat won't quit cabinet despite disagreement over way government raised bread prices.
- Authorities start releasing detainees arrested in bread riots after questioning.
- King says Jordan depends on its workers to build itself and achieve self-reliance.
- Deputies and senators of southern governates confirm loyalty of residents to Hashemite leadership.
- Amman governor denies granting permission to stage "march of one million hungry" called by Islamic Action Front on Friday.
- Prime Minister Kabariti meets trade union council on Thursday.
- Amman prosecutor detains chief editor of Al-Bilad weekly and reporter at magazine.
- Investors expect upward trend in Amman Financial Market to continue.
- Opposition deputies call on government to engage in real dialogue.
- Start of project to set up peace park in Aqaba.
